title: 8 axle flat car in N scale

description.text:
This is an 8 axle flat car based on the QTTX 130556; http://www.solrswat.ca/1_EquipmentRoster/Freight/TTX_QTTX_Flats/8_axle_FD/QTTX130550-130556.htm
This heavy duty, drop deck flat car is used for very heavy, tall loads, often transformers or machinery.
You will need 4 n scale intermountain trucks and a pair of brake wheels to complete this build.
Build 1 deck, 2 bolsters and 4 pins. The pins will be used for the trucks. You can use 1.75mm filament to pin the bolsters to the deck.
Note that there are 2 sets of STLs. The ones with the HQ at the end are high quality (and experimental) renders with more details meant to be printed on a Formslab (or similar). They will not print on a typical FDM printer.

Triangle code is thanks to Tim Koopman; https://github.com/tkoopman/Delta-Diamond/blob/master/OpenSCAD/Triangles.scad

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The deck should be printed on its side and doesn't need support. The bolster is a pain to print. It does need support but MakerWare doesn't do a good job. I used MeshMixer supports successfully.

Assembly

Cut the couplers off of 2 of your trucks. Pin the 4 trucks to the bolsters. The ones that you cut down go in the open area, the stock ones under the bolster deck. Place a short piece of filament in the holes in the deck. You may want a touch of super glue. Put the filament through the bolsters and melt the ends, mushrooming them so the bolsters won't fall off. Glue the brake wheels to the brake wheel stands, the wheels should face in, towards the deck.

description.text:
Bought the Geologic Plastip Dartboard and found out that it uses keyhole mounting.

My mum doesn't allow drilling of holes in the walls.

Hence I designed this thing to allow me to use 3M command strips to securely mount it up on to the wall. :)

I've weighed the dartboard and is approximately 860+ grams. Each strip that I bought can hold 450 grams hence the base plastic plate is large enough to hold 3 strips.

These are designed to slip on the end of a stepper motor to seal the end from the environment. The idea is to solder or otherwise make the wire connections, then silicone the cap and seal in place with the wire extending through the hole in the seal.

They were designed to fit NEMA 23 KL23H2100-50-4B and NEMA 34 KL34H120-60-4A motors from Automation Technologies, previously Kelinginc. They'll probably fit other motors too, be sure to share what motors you use them on!

print_settings.Notes:: 0.28mm layer height is a good coarse/fast setting for my printer. Any height that your printer likes should work fine. title: HS1177 camera mount for Martian Quadcopter

description.text:
This is a rework of @jimmac's Martian HS1177 camera mount. That one didn't quite fit my Martian (lots of different Martians out there, you know?), so I used it as a guideline and designed a similar one. I made this very quickly in TinkerCAD, so it's not as elegant as @jimmac's. However, I redesigned it slightly to not need supports while printing.

I printed this in TPU, but it should work fine in other plastics. I prefer the flexibility that TPU gives.

To see if it fits yours, it's designed for standoffs with a 5mm diameter that are 35mm tall. Their centers are 34mm apart, which makes their insides 29mm apart and their outsides 39mm apart.

description.text:
Hi guys, these are some TMNT weapons I designed and printed with my son, still a work in progress so let me know what you think about shape and size if you make them! I just wasn't that excited about the ones that came with the figures, and I especially like that the nunchuks have actual chain links, I wasn't sure that would work at first but after you kind of break them free gently they work pretty well! I printed these flat with support, hence the little tabs to space the part up on the "with tabs" versions of the bow staff and sai, but you could try other ways.
Please note these are only intended to be toy-sized pretend weapons for Ninja Turtle action figures!

I created this to fit the Tevo without having to change the X carriage. This is suitable for the Tevo Tarantula that comes with the auto level sensor.

Used 3mm screws to secure it (as there aren't any smaller ones in the local hardware store)

author: Sacrisnc

description.text: Here is a project born out of a unique set of circumstance. I've been surprised how many people in the 3D community find themselves in the same strange predicaments so I'll post this. It may inspire you. It all started when I purchased a new case for my smart phone. Not just any case, but a Qi chargeable Extra Battery case for my iPhone 6 (see Item One in pictures, links posted below). Now previously, I purchased a Smart & Easy magnetic phone mount for my car. Really slick (see item two). The problem is, that the metal disk for the magnetic holder interferes with the Qi charging capabilities. I was eventually able to find a location low enough on the charger that allowed it to charge in my stand charger (see item 3). The problem was the charger next to my bed just wasn't strong enough to get around the displaced magnetic field. So I decided to make my own. Step 1, make a new coil that aligns to the height and shape of above the magnetic disk encompassing the internal coils. To do this I purchased a DIY charger kit for $8.99 on Amazon. I created the alignment plate, unsoldered and unwound the coil. Wrapped it onto the plate using a layer of contact cement to keep it in place. I re-soldered the coil to the circuit board and used adhesive to mount the circuit board to the back of the plate. The box was designed to accept the plate as the floor, it too, was glued in place with a bead of silicon to pin it down and ensure the edges of the vinyl weren't rough. From there, the USB circuit board was mounted to the back and the feet were printed. The feet have a cup design allowing me to put a daub of silicone rubber in each one and mashing it down with a wet finger created a non-skid foot. It would be a hell of a lot easier to buy the little stick-on feet from the hardware store but I was too lazy to make the run.

Incipio Battery Case: https://www.amazon.com/iPhone-Battery-Incipio-offGRID-Backup/dp/B00TRN18I4/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1469424783&sr=8-2&keywords=incipio+iphone+6+battery+case

Smart & Easy Magnetic Cell Phone Holder: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00Q8XGLA6/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Wireless Qi Charging DIY Kit: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00V2HL4Y6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This 6 packer is made of .093 (3/32) thick clear acrylic.

I took the .dxf file from timogiles and manually tweaked it to work with .093" thick material.  I used common clear acrylic from the window section at Home Depot as the material.  This was laser cut.  Also the 4-40 screws were shortened to 3/8" long...I used brass in this one.
Works well, and looks pretty nice.  Acrylic doesn't char at the ends or leave burn marks like wood does.  Leaves a nice polished edge.  
The .093" thick material is a bit too thin to be comfortable.  There is thicker stuff at the store, but it's a bit pricey.  
Some strategically placed LED's would really make this stand out I think.

title: Ikea Jansjo Red Light Filter Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a filter holder for the Ikea Jansjo lamp. This was designed to adapt the Ikea Jansjo lamp to double as a red light at night to preserve my night vision for astronomy.

The filter holder is made in two pieces. The inner part is snug to the lamp. The outer part holds the filter in place and is snug to the inner part. The filter holder works using press fits so it may take some sanding to get the diameters just right. But because of the press fit there is no white light leaks of any kind.

FYI, the filter I use is LEE FILTERS 027 MEDIUM RED

description.text:
A door chock design I remixed from schlem's original door chock design.

Here is schlem's original design:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93859

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5EoTQBYERzD

If you have any design ideas or suggestions, I'd love to hear them so I can refine this.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

At least 40%

Notes:

You will need to rotate it so it's upside down, having the large notch facing upward, that way you don't have to print with supports

Infill you don't need to ramp up super high, I keep mine low to save on filament.

114mm Long x 38mm high x 30mm wide if you print it at 100% scale

So I've wanted to make a custom door chock of my own for a while and I found a few designs on Thingiverse that I wasn't 100% pleased with.

So I decided to make my own, and add a few features I'd have liked.

I took the original design, and used the Square Hole tool on Tinkercad to create the holes I wanted. Basically just rotating the square and sizing it where I wanted it, and it came out rather good in my opinion.

It's designed so you can use it as both a door chock, and if you inside it sideways, and turn it, it can also be used in the door jamb itself.

The chunk cut out near the bottom of the chock is so you can put it on your helmet if you'd like, it's designed to have the strap go in there. I'm hoping the cut isn't too deep making it difficult to remove.

I have also included versions with and without holes, and with and without the notch for the helmet strap.

The hole is 6mm large so you can fit most kinds of rope or a ziptie or whatever your fancy is.

title: Cable Chain Remix for Pro Operation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of spauda01's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1167746 to allow the chain to operate as per how they are installed on industrial equipment - the two 'legs' of chain run parallel with a single loop at the far end which constrains the cable to a certain diameter of bend.

To do this required the ends remodelling slightly to allow correct orientation, and the positioning is now such that it fixes to the rear of the rails to allow unimpeded motion and the required space above for the loop to gather.

You will need the regular inbetween chain pieces from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1167746

The regular chain worked perfectly on my standard D-bot build, but as I'm now going a bit taller there were going to be problems when the bed was at a low position with the chain hitting the rear side rail.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

When printing orient the parts so that the groove to go in the V-slot is running vertical and the screw hole is nearest the bed.

title: Convenient Spool Holder and filament guide for Prusa i3 mk2

description.text:
[Edit 25/05/17]
Having just received big 2Kg spool which are 20 cm wide, I added a large version of filament guide. A long threaded rode is then needed for axis.

[Edit 11/05/16]
I made a new axis with smaller diameter that roll smoother on the arms. The file is "Spool Holder v4 - Axis.stl"

[Edit 09/16/16]
I've been requested for the sources of the thing, so I added the 123D Design source file. enjoy !

The full print is possible on a Prusa i3 MK2 with 250 210 mm heatbed. For 200200 heatbed however you will need to do multiple prints from individual stl file.

All the new files are labelled with version 3.25

[Edit 08/14/16]
In order to reduce stress on the filament when the extruder is at top Z position, I made some modification from the initial design: Longer arm and bigger hole in the filament guide, as well as a reversible montage, allowing two position with 5 mm higher or lower position. The filament guide is then higher with less angle on filament in high extruder position.
[End of edit]

Having a Prusa i3 mk2, the wide heatbed (250 mm) gave me some issue with the filament going sometime out of the spool when the extruder is on the very side, especially for new filament spool.

I then modified my initial spool holder to include a filament guide that prevent filament to be pulled from the side. In addition, I refined the initial design to make it easier to change the spool.

New version have then:

  • Included filament guide, prevending the filament to slide on the side of the spool.
  • easier spool change, no more screws on the side, just pull the cylinder, change spool and put it back
  • automatic centering spool, due to the cylinder specific profile
  • Large generic spool support, up to 140 mm wide
  • Easy to print design, every parts hold on a single print on a standard 200 mm * 200 mm heatbed.
  • Designed for Prusa i3 mk2, but should be used on any 6mm frame printer.

Just add a 200 mm M8 threaded pole in the cylinder and optionally use two bolt to maintain it. In case you do not have threaded rod, I added a printable axis that can be used instead (but I did not try it yet).

This is my initial design, so far the tests are good, but I will probably make some additional fine tuning later and add a version for M6 threaded pole.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 original MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 nm

Infill:

22 %

Notes:

Use support just for the cylinder below bolt slot

title: Dyson DC to Kärcher Vacuumcleaner Nozzle Adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter to use a standard vacuum-cleaner nozzle on a Dyson DC vacuum-cleaner.
https://youtu.be/uU6PHKfvmAo

It is a remix of the Design from KHecker Adapter.
I reinforced the section with the nut, where the Dyson locks in.
I enlarged the outer diameter of the section witch fit into the nozzle.
The inside of the adapter is now optimized for less air drag.

Update:
After few times of use the adapter it was broken because I used i bit more force to retrace nozzle from under a furniture. After inspecting the breakage and the according layer in the slicer software, I fount the weak point.(see the print screen in the gallery)
Now you find a reinforced version to download. I recommend to print this and to take care that the cross section showed has a infill of 100%.

title: GATETRIX V1 / LIGHTRIX V1 modular gate system for Tiny Whoop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
GATETRIX / LIGHTRIX - 3D printed modular Tiny Whoop gate System

RELEASE VERSION

Update 26.11.2016:
Added two new pieces, which are supposed to give your gate structure more stability:

  • connector_straight_circle_legs_stronger_version.stl
  • base_stand_connector_for_use_with_rods_stronger_version.stl

Also released GATETRIX V2 (a different/new design concept)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1917733

Update 19.11.2016:
Created new Version of the straight rod extender (with a little hinge). Helps securing the extenders when mounting them upside down. The length has also been slightly modified (it's a bit smaller now). I suggest to use the new Version from now on. A V2 for the circle extender is available too.
Gatetrix V2 is coming soon.

21.08.2016: RELEASE VERSION - The System state no longer is "work in progress". Many tests have been made and the system now is considered as a release version.

I would be pleased to see your gate creations in the make section.

Developed for easy and quick printing. Optimized for 200x200mm print surface. Only a few parts need support structures (Rod extenders and the flag base connector). All (almost) connectors can be printed without Support. Just be sure to place the pieces correctly onto the print bed. You printer should be able to print bridges quite well (however, the gaps which have to be filled are quite small (aprox. 5mm).

At the moment there are about 30 different pieces available. You can send me further ideas via PM. For construction of standard shape gates (square/circle), there are only a few different rods/connectors needed. The other pieces are optional for creative people to build more complex gate structures. I've built a 1,80m (aprox. 6ft) high gate structure (check out the pictures).

Update 07.08.2016:
Since all connector parts have been redesign (longer connector pieces and getting narrower towards the inside, it's easier to fit the rods and connectors together. I heard from many People that the 4.98mm Version fits the best, but you should try it yourself. Different Printer, different precision/fitting.

Printer calibration/Print settings:
The parts need to fit snugly, for keeping the gates together but also providing a easy disassembly.

The usage of different filament colors (altough it's the same material) results in divergent fits. Idealy all parts are printed with the same filament type/color and the same print settings.
The bright filament colors are visible best (white, grey, etc. ). I recommend the usage of PETG. It's strong an flexible and therefore you can be a bit more rough during assembly and it won't brake so easily. Also it is possible to build round shaped gates with rods only, due to their certain flexibility (check out the pictures).

All here shown parts were aprox. 1100g filament and were printed in about 48 hours (0.3mm layer height, 2 shells, 3 top/bottom layers, 20% infill ... rods can be printed without infill, it's quicker but also not as tough and will cost you the flexibility).

The system is modular and extendable. It's quickly assembled and disassembled. It can be stored place saving. Due to the modular plug/connector system you can get creative by creating your own obstacles/gates/whatever.

The gates are visible very good with white/grey color filament by themselves. With the extenders the visibility gets even better of course and you get the ability to mount modular LED Systems (check out the pictures).

Have fun

Update History:

22.08.2016:
With just one new connector piece (flag_base_connector_for_use_with_rods) and already existing pieces, we get awesome huge (80-100cm) illuminated flags!

21.08.2016:
Added a new connector which enables you to use straight rods as base/legs (base_stand_connector_for_use_with_rods.stl). The 19cm base connector is ok for small gates, but if getting bigger the gate will fall, therefore this improvement. Works great, because the connectors for the leg rods are angled slightly, so there's tension created which gives the gates perfect stability.
Added a new Version of the cable router for easier routing cables, when working with a LED System.
Removed some obsolete parts.

07.08.2016:
Redesigned all connector pieces (extended the connectors by 3mm and the inside is now getting narrower towards the inside (1,5° angle). This should give you a good and snug fit.

05.08.2016: Redesigned the straight connector. The new one (V2) is a little bit longer (had issues with to loose fitting rods pushing each other out of place) and the most important thing: The inside of the connectors is slightly angled (getting narrower towards the middle). This improvements addresses the fitting tolerance issue which printers have (with different Filaments). So with the new connectors alls of my rods from almost 7 different Filament Colors fit together well. I've also added a V3 straight connector which is supposed to be used with very flexible Filaments like Ninjaflex which eleminates the tolerance issue completely. The shells simply are a little bit thicker.

Also added a variety of connectors with additional angled connectors, which for example can be used to connect gate shapes with different heights for more stability and to create a tunnel type gate (check out the pictures).

I also discovered that it's possible to form a gate only consisting of rods (see the pictures). So with Filaments which have a flexible property (not Flex Filament), you can simply bend the gate to the desired shape. PETG works great. ABS should work to. PLA should be to brittle for this.
Enjoy!

03.08.2016: Added new shape rod (eighth circle) with extender element. Needs 8 pieces for a whole circle and is quite bigger than the quarter circle Version. Also added another connector (straight connector with leg hole and additional connector (angled). Also added another cable router with a bigger hole.

27.07.2016: Added 5 new connector pieces (straight connector with leg hole and additional connectors)

(The following was written on the first release and should be obsolete due to the new connector design. I'll leave it however to let people be aware of the possible fitting issues and how to resolve them)

Originally the pieces where developed for the 5.00mm rod version. Then I went out of filament and had to use a different color (same material).
The result was, that the rods didn't fit snugly into the connectors anymore with the 5.0mm version rods. Therefore I made 6 further variants (4.97mm, 4.98mm, 4.99mm, 5.01mm, 5.02mm, 5.03mm). The 4.98mm variant was perfect with the other filament color.
You possibly can adjust the result by altering the flow factor as well.
In all cases you should be sure your printer is calibrated correctly (Extruder/Jerk/Acceleration) and make a test print with a straight connector and the 6 rod variants, so you can tell which one fits the best.

description.text:
This is a .50 calibre BMG round as per plans found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.50_BMG

I use just the shell hold my bullet chilli at work - looks great a red chilli popping out of a BMG shell as if it was the bullet. The one at work is printed in black and contrasts well with the chilli.

This has been optimised to print with Vase mode - it is far quicker than using layer by layer printing (as other versions of this model do) and is very strong - looks great too.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Prints well in Spiral (Vase) Mode with Simplify3D.

There is a trick to printing the bottom of the shell - at 0.2 layer height you need 11 bottom solid layers, or the print will collapse (90 degree bend 2mm from bottom).

For the bullet: print slowly, and set slicer to slow down as layer gets faster - if you don't do this you will have to cool aggressively as you get to the point of the projectile, or risk a soggy mess.

Depending on your cooling and printer setup you might find the projectile just a little too small to sit solidly in the shell - if you find this scale to 102% or 103% and you will find it fits well.
Used wikipedia shell/bullet dimensions to design in Fusion 360. Sketched profile, revolved to solid, then converted to a shell with 0.4mm using the shell tool.

This is a set of very basic tests of the mechanics of your printer. The intention is that they should be fairly slicer-independent, and they should each, as far as possible, isolate a single feature of printer performance.

XYZ size: measure the size of a print in line with the X Y and Z towers. Changes in these sizes are a first-order effect of miscalibrated arm lengths. Each size can be measured externally, as the size of an object, or internally, as the size of a void, so that over/under extrusion doesn't enter into the calculation.

Gap test: prints a series of square blocks in rectangular holes with thinner and thinner gaps on two sides. This isolates how much of a gap you need for straight walls to prevent them fusing; it's remarkably small on my printer (only the 0.1 mm gap was fused).

Tilted-gap test: Like the previous test but with sloping gaps (that is, overhangs). This sort of gap occurs in herringbone gears, and keeping sloping surfaces from fusing probably requires more of a gap. This is a work in progress; it's a more difficult print than the others.

Corner-cutting tests: One of the reasons printers often produce too-small circular holes is that filament has a tendency to cut corners. This test provides positive and negative corners of various angles, all nominally 10 mm apart, for you to measure and find out how serious a problem this is for you. The corners are all between relatively long straight sides, so path simplification should confuse the issue.
From biker to bikers!=)

author: random

description.text:
In my previous derivative of Rasle500's great design I just made a longer handle.
This thing make that handle empty, adds some threads an introduces a cap to be bolted in those threads.
Now you have a handle that is also an storage box!

Hope you were not printing the previous handle !
Print "test handle.stl" to check that everything is fine when printing the threads. You may need to slow down your printer's rates.
Once that kind of nut that I call "test handle" has printed fine, you're good to print the real handle of taste. You'll find here the one that's 90mm long (120mm end to end). There are few more in the ZIP file and, of course, you can use the OpenSCAD script to change the length to taste.
Then print "015 test cap.stl" (it should print fine with the same settings than the test handle) and check how the two test parts fit. Too loose? Tight? Pick another from the ZIP file or make your custom one with the OpenSCAD script.
BTW: 015 stands for 0.15mm of gap between nut and bolt, ehem, it's not really true but we can just let it like this.
Once you have find the correct size, print the corresponding cap and are you're done!
Few more words (sorry)...
The ZIP contains the rest of stl files to complete the assembly, check out thing:16682 for more details.
If your printer is able to go higher than 120mm print a taller handle. The 6mm drill bit just fits into the 90mm handle!
I printed the handle with quite a weird parameters... Feedrate: 18, Flowrate: 205, layer height:0.34, 3 perimeter shells! 0.0001 infill. It's solid as a rock but it took 34cc and 3h45 to print (0.6mm diameter of extruded plastic)

Drill hole M3 screw or other suitable.
Gewinde M3 bohren oder passende andere Schraube.

comments.text: OK, so this is only meant to block the circuit breaker in the OFF position. That can be a good idea when working on a circuit that should not accidentally be turned on. It is a really bad idea to use it to block the circuit breaker in the ON position. The circuit breaker looks to be symmetrical so it is up to the user to ensure never to use it with the ON position.
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: I guess you can not prevent a breaker to "fall" with this one monted in "on position". But I think this is great because it is to use in "OFF" position when doing work on instalation and you do not want anyone to set power on wires you work with!

description.text:
A longer frame is needed for longer things - thus we (Bettina E.B.J. and Mogens H) have extended the P3Steel in the x- direction. With a special thanks to Kasper T. K. for helping with the drawing process when our competences were to small.

This is ONLY the additional components needed for making a wider version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579315 with a building surface of 220x220x620 mm^3.

1) You will need extra motor for z (or maybe not we have only used two motors)
2) Extra linear barrings (x4) and rods (x2) for z
3) Longer rods for x
4) Longer (x) more (z) belts
5) Bed heater custom silicone pad for heat bed (optional)

The assembly is identical http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579315 and you will need most of the components from the AUP3Steel to make this version.

All drawings are attached in .pdf (for visdual inspection) and .dxf for laser cutting and modification.

Enjoy and have fun.

Notes:

Laser cutting

remixed_from.author: dintid
remixed_from.title: Spoolholder with mount for 2020 Extrusion I-Type 5

description.text:
This is a remix of two separate spool holders. I wanted a universal spool holder that mounted on my pegboard, but I wasn't a fan of most of the ones on Thingiverse. So, I modified an existing pegboard mount to hold my favorite spool holder.

This spool holder runs on bearings and is universal to just about every size of spool.

What you need to assemble the unit:
3 x M8 nuts. (5/16th also works) - http://amzn.to/2hdztwf
Some 8mm threadded rod. (5/16th also works) - http://amzn.to/2gNYK2V
2x 608ZZ bearings.- http://amzn.to/2g6naFQ
6 x M3 bolts in various lengths to assemble arm and bracket.
6 x M3 nuts. - http://amzn.to/2helg62

Printer:

FolgerTech FT-5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

High

Notes:

This print is basically two components: The spool holder (Two piece screw) and the mount (arms and bracket).

I highly urge the use of ABS for this.

Print the Spool holder parts using the same resolution and infill or things will fit funny. Use supports to help fill in the gaps in between the build plate and bearing insert. Infill should be about 40% or higher.

Print the mount with a high infill for strength. Use supports for the straight arm for the nut cutout.

Assembly

Assemble the mount using the M3 bolts and nuts.

Attach the 8mm (or 5/16th) rod to the mount. Secure it in place using two nuts, one on each side of the straight arm of the mount.

Insert a 608ZZ bearing into each side of the 'inner part' threaded side of spool holder. Slide on to rod and then secure on using another M8 (or 5/16th) nut.

The Spool nut then screws over the inner part to complete the holder.

I recommend screwing and unscrewing the two spool holder parts several times to help wear down the extra material around the threading.

title: Super8, Standard 8mm, and 16mm Film Reel Generator

description.text:
This is a generator for film reels for Super8, standard 8mm, and 16mm film reels. I also included a set of 3 standard sizes for each version as STL files. The reels have 3 insert for the films in the core to make it easy to fit the film onto the spool.

The generator is fully parameterized, so you can change the exact specifications in any way you want. It is also easy to control the how narrow the center hole for the spool is and how tight the fitting of the two halves is. In the .scad file there is documentation on all the variables you can set, and some suggestions for standard sizes, that i used to generate the included set.
You can also use the customizer from thingiverse on this generator.

The reels consists of a bottom and top part, which should be printed separately and which fit nicely together, only in the correct orientation.

I printed the Super8 ones myself and they work very well if printed correctly!

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25 layer height

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Every printer is different so whether the two halves fit nicely together, and if the reel fits on the spool nicely depends on which printer and printer settings you use.

There are two variables in the .scad file (coreTightness and fittingSpacer) to control the exact spacing for the middle hole and the fitting holes.

My suggestion is to print the smallest (3 inch) size bottom first. Check if it fits the spool nicely. If not, change the coreTightness and print again. If you get a nice fitting version, print the top half. If that doesn't fit well on the bottom half, change the fittingSpacer and print the top again. If it fits, then you know you got the right settings and can print the bigger ones as your please.

My settings: I used coreTightness = 0.2 and fittingSpacer = 0.4 with an extrusion multiplier of 0.9 using M-ABS to make the reel fit well.
I changed the coreTightness back to 0.0 in the scad file now, as I assume most people print with higher extrusion multipliers.

If the fitting between the two halves happens to be very tight, no post-printing is necessary. If they are a bit lose I suggest some superglue between the halves (make sure you don't get glue in the wrong places). If they don't fit together at all, or they are way too lose, I suggest editing the fittingSpacer variable and reprinting.

I only own 3inch, 5inch, and 7inch Super8 reels myself. I based the standard sizes on those. For the standard 8mm reels, the hole in the center is smaller and different, and for the 16mm it appears to be a square hole. I modeled these, but I could not test them or compare them to original reels. Please let me know when they are not correct and I will fix them.

This is a model of the classic 1959 Cadillac convertible.
Designed in Blender and printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 in PLA.
There's no dashboard yet...

The model was designed in Blender and then printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2.
I used 0.15 mm resolution for everything except the front grill which was done at 0.10 mm. It probably doesn't make much of a difference.
I used a scaling factor of %1000 in MakerWare.
If you go smaller you may lose detail and some of the parts (such as the side mirror) will be too small to work with. Here's a summary of each part:
1) Front body: Print using rafts and supports and orient the part with the open end on the build plate. (the supports are needed for cavity of the interior).
2) Rear body: Print using rafts and supports with the open end on the build plate.
3) Front bumper: No supports needed. Orient the flat back part on the build plate.
4) Front grill: No supports needed. Orient the back flat part on the build plate.
5) Front seats and rear seats. No supports needed. Orient the bottom of the seat on the build plate.
6) Rear bumper. You will need to use supports for this with the back of the bumper on the build plate.
7) Front and rear wheels: No supports needed. They must be printed lying with the back of the wheel (flat part) on the build plate. Note that the rear wheels are cut in half so they will look like they are under the rear wheel covers when glued on. There is a slight cavity in the front wheel wells where you can place the front wheels and glue them to the supports in the body undercarriage.
8) Steering wheel: One side of the steering wheel is flat. Make sure you put that side on the build plate. The steering wheel fits over the steering column (friction fit). You'll notice that this steering wheel is a little over-sized...
9) Steering column: No supports needed. One end of this column is angled so you can glue it to the interior at the right orientation. Make sure the other end is on the build plate when printing.
10) Side mirror: Again, print so the mirror faced up and the back is on the build plate. You may have to snip a bit of the arm before you glue it to the body. Perhaps later I'll make a slot for it.
11) Windshield: No supports needed. Print with the narrower (flat) edge on the build plate. I switched filaments and used translucent. That should do it for the printing. I strongly recommend painting first before gluing.
Sand the front and rear body parts where they join before you glue to make the fit as clean as possible. Using rafts when you print really helps make the join as good as possible.
The more time you take on the details (sanding, painting, etc), the better the result!

description.text:
A mount for the excellent E3D Titan and MakerFarm Pegasus, with a metal X carriage, optionally, with an 18mm inductive probe mount.

I have provided versions both with and without the probe mount and both 20mm and 48mm long NEMA 17 motors. I use a 20mm pancake motor with the Titan. It works flawlessly and makes for a lighter X axis.

The supplied STLs have a 5mm thick plate for mounting the Titan and the motor. I find that this works well with Isograph's Titan Radial Fan Mount and the long mounting screws supplied with the Titan. I did have to use a 10mm M3 bolt (instead of the supplied 8 or 12mm) to secure the bottom right titan mount point to the motor.

The motor length, motor tolerance and mount plate thickness are configurable. The OnShape document has these dimensions exposed as variables that you can copy and then change to suit your requirements. After tweaking these dimensions, you can export the mount, and optionally the probe mount, as STL.

Probe offsets for Marlin firmware are -36mm X, -26m Y for the 20mm motor and -36mm X, -52mm Y for a 48mm motor.

If you have the 8mm lead screw upgrade then you will lose about 2cm of printable area. I man make another version of the titan mount with the motor offset towards the X idler to regain this lost area.

title: Tray for Primula Drip Coffee Maker

description.text:
We recently "fired" Keurig as our coffee maker (expensive, wasteful, mediocre coffee) and picked up a $20 Primula one cup drip coffee maker with stainless steel filter as a stop-gap until we figured out which coffee maker to buy next. I'd forgotten how good locally roasted, fresh ground coffee could be.

In terms of convenience, it turns out that an electric kettle and the Primula is almost as easy to use as the Keurig. Given the superior coffee, lower cost and zero waste, I can live with measuring a scoop and a quick filter rinse.

The only complaint is, the drip maker, well... drips. Frequently a drop of coffee grounds hits the floor on the way to dump the grounds and then you get a little water on the counter after rinsing. No big deal, but I decided to design and 3D print a custom tray to contain the drips, and here it is. Works great, BTW.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A set of damper, spring loaded feet to reduce vibration and noise on the Up! Mini.
I have been using these for the past 12 months and they work well, but YMMV!

I used springs purchased from Bunnings (Australia) 27mm long x 11mm o/s dia x 1.1mm thick.
Due to the addtional weight on the rear of the printer, the front top section has a recess for the spring to allow for the difference in compression - this may need top be modified if using different size/strength springs.
Print four of the bases and two each of the tops.
Push fit the springs to both base and top and then fit the assembly over the printers existing molded feet.

Step files are included if you wish to modify them to suit different sized springs.

description.text:
v0.8, Monday 22 August 2016.
UPDATE, 31 Oct 2016: a new improved version has been published as: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1861347

This is a very first attempt to design a (full-parametric, customizable) prototype extruder for plastic pellets that can work for common 3D printers. The real extruder should be obviously printed out of metal (stainless steel, probably) at a smaller scale and many parts will have to be added/improved (for example: the head should be able to accept "standard" screw-in nozzles; the axis should be coupled with a stepper motor, possibly with a geared reduction; a controlled heating system should be applied around the stator for melting the pellets; different types of flange should be added for connecting the extruder to common 3D printers; etc...). Anyway, this prototype can already be printed in plastic and it may be hopefully good for some preliminary tests with "soft" pellets (chocolate granules? Play-Doo???), extruding "by hand" and without a heating system. We still haven't tested it, really... But we plan to do it soon, and to post here the results and an improved version of the design.

title: F.A.R.A (Four Axis Robotic Arm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's my four axis robotic arm.
It consists of several parts and can be printed and assembled according to your use.
All parts composing the arm are easy to find online or in stores.

You can control this arm easily with a program board as an Arduino UNO board and A4988 stepsticks.

With this project, you can build, modify and improve a robotic arm completely adapted to your project.
And this arm can help you achieve all your research projects or otherwise.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm or 0.25 mm

Infill:

15% or 20% (Honeycomb)

I modeled this arm with Design Spark Mechanical.

This arm is very easy to print and assemble. I modeled all the parts for enter in almost any printer.
You don't need to print parts with support.

There is a feature to print these files: “Fixation moteur inf” and “Support moteur B” because it takes place a ball bearing inside the piece during printing.

Overview & Background:

It's a robotic arm consists of several parts and can be printed and assembled according to your use.
You can make your arm with longer or shorter segments or to an arm with more or less axis.
This project is really flexible and can adapt your skills to grow with your discoveries and learning.

Objectives:

You can develop your knowledge in many areas:
Mathematics: calculate the angle of each axis according to the engine displacement, place the arm in a system with polar coordinates, calculate the torque of each engine ...
Mechanical: assemble the arm, discover how each axis and gripper works ...
Electronics: make a schematic with the components of the arm and will help you to make it work, experiment with a breadbord, discover how a microcontroller works (Arduino for example) ...
Programming: discover the different programming languages, create your program and move the arm for your project ...

Audiences:

I think this project is very interesting for a lot of different people and grades or age cathegories.
You can print and build the arm with only two or three axes and moove it with a PC and a programming board.
(There are lots of tutorials on the internet that can help you and I will soon complete this article with an electronic schematic based on an Arduino UNO and A4988 stepsticks, I am also working on a program to use the arms independently only with an arduino board)
But the project is also very scalable:
You can build your arm in shape and size you wish to fit your project.
You can build all the tools that you want to replace the gripper.
You can also scale your project based on your discoveries concerning the programming and the various sensors that you can connect to an Arduino board ...
This project has no limits with your imagination.

Subjects:

You can develop many topics with this project: Math, science, mechanics, electronics, programming ...

Skills Learned (Standards):

Board programming.
Operation of stepper motors
Different gears systems
Positioning of objects in space (Cartesian coordinates, angular coordinates ...)
Operation of servos
3D Slicing
Designing
3D Printing

Lesson / Activity:

This project can be separated into several lessons in three main themes
Mechanical part:

  • Study of 3D files
  • Study of mechanical stress
  • Study of gears systems
  • Study of the torque and selection of suitable motors for each axis
  • Creating a Personal Project
  • Selection of required parts to the project
  • Study of 3D printing
  • Study of 3D slicing
  • Printing parts
     (Characteristic for parts containing ball bearings to place in the piece during printing)
  • Arm assembly

Electronic part:

  • Study of programming boards (Arduino ...)
     (Several activities : codes, basic electronics, using sensors ...)
  • Study of stepsticks
  • Creating and using a schematic
  • Welding and protection of electronic components
  • Creation of the electronic circuit

Programming part:

  • Study of the main programming languages
  • Creation of the first codes to control a stepper motor
  • Move the axis one by one
     (For me I came to this step! :)
  • Creation of a program to move the arm, all axes simultaneously

Of course, you can make as many lessons as you want and develop this project with your project: changing pieces, create new, create new grippers and tools, add new sensors ...

The programming part has not limits, unleash your imagination :)

Duration:

It takes about 100 hours to print a four axis arm.
Then it takes 2 or 3 hours to assemble.
With Arduino and stepsticks board make electronic part takes about 1 hour.
For the moment I don't yet perfectly mastered all the programming part. For me this is the part that takes me more time ... There are a lot of very good tutorials on the internet and to moove the arm basically just takes about 2 or 3 hours.

But for a teacher, according to the project, there maybe hundreds of hours of lessons and activities!

Preparation:

You have to have some basic knowledge about the functioning of a 3D printer, but I modeled all the arm to make it easy to print.
The pieces are small and can print on almost any printer models.
The pieces don't need support.

For the mechanical part, you need some basic tools (pliers, wrenches and screwdriver ...)
For electronics, you need a multimeter, a soldering ...

Here is the list of all the materials you need to build a four axis arm:
(And some useful links;)

All unprinted parts are easy to find online or in store:
 - 3 stepper motors (1.8 ° / step)
 - 1 stepper motor with planetary gear system (http://www.robotshop.com/ca/en/12v-17a-416oz-geared-bipolar-stepper-motor.html)
 - 2 micro servo 9g
 - M5 threaded rod
 - M8 threaded rod
 - Several screws, nuts and washers (M5, M8 and M10)
 - Several ball bearings (M8, M10 and M5 http://www.ebay.fr/itm/10Pcs-Roulement-a-Bille-Bearings-Palier-Lineaire-Hautes-Performances-Haut-Gamme-/351758729407?var=&hash=item51e67440bf:m:m0294h_6SnLeMTPuBrynDpw)
 - Several couplers (http://www.ebay.fr/itm/5-6-8-10-12mm-Coupling-Rigid-Shaft-Coupling-Coupler-Tighten-Screw-Stepper-Motor-/262158277792?var=&hash=item3d09d9dca0:m:myluG0YVkR2WJEUzQrtotcw)
 - 2 springs
 - 1 gear "Meccano" and 1 worm gear "Meccano" (ebay);)
stainless steel or aluminum tube diameter 10mm
 - 4 switches (http://www.ebay.fr/itm/5-x-AC-125V-1A-Inverseur-miniature-Micro-interrupteur-a-levier-Y3-/282030545146?hash=item41aa5498fa:g:BnYAAOSwWF5XLgNr)
 - Some PLA;)

References :

I spent a lot and a lot of time to design and improve my four axis robotic arm but I didn't have references or links. I was inspired by the indutriels robotic arm ...

Regarding the electronics / programming, I found many very good tutorials on the internet (thank you google!)

About Arduino, here is the link the most useful for me (in French): http://eskimon.fr/category/arduino/partie-1

Rubric & assessment:

With this project, you can build, modify and improve a robotic arm completely adapted to your project.
But with this arm, you can do whatever you want!
Research work, pick and place projects, Artificial Inteligence projects, Art project ....

Handouts & Assets:

I am working on a complete electronic schematic based on an Arduino UNO board and stepsticks to control the arm.
(I'll post this schematic as soon as it is completed)
I am also working on a program to move the arm smoothly, all axes simultaneously and without USB connection with a PC.
I have not much knowledge in this area but I work a lot and I'll post you my codes as soon as possible.

I posted the "F.A.R.A_V7_Gripper 1.stl" file to help you visualize all the parts and to help you to assemble the arm.

I hope this thing details are clear. I'd be happy to help you in your projects and to answer your questions.

title: Up Mini Heat Bed Support
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These parts replace the single "L" shaped support piece on the underside of the heatbed that connects it to the metal frame.
The problem with the original design is that it is fixed, while the outside of the bed is spring loaded, often resulting in a non level print bed.

The parts are designed as a direct replacement using the same hole centres/sizes as the existing part. It is however, a good idea to grind/file down the screws so that they don't protrude through either part (as this may restrict movement depending on the thickness of the printbed used).
The male part is designed to be a snug fit, but not tight. The female part is fixed to the frame while the male fixes to the heat bed. Once the print board is fitted it allows the centre of the bed to rise or fall to match the external edges, while still being fixed laterally and more importantly, remain flat.
There are two male parts included, one for use on the standard perf board setup, while the second ("Male- Adjustable") is for use on this floating/adjustable bed mod:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1690155

If you are using this with the an unmodified bed setup, take care when inserting or removing the perf board as the heat bed may move until the perf board pushes the heatbed down and locks it into place.

comments.text: Does this require a spring to be placed underneath the movable part?
comments.author: Xonor13

comments.text:
No it doesn't.
It's just there to allow the centre of the bed to move up and down with the rest of the bed, while still retaining its position in the X and Y direction. Just make sure the fit of the male into the female part isn't too tight as to hinder this movement.

comments.text:
Great to hear that you're giving the bed levelling mod a go! It makes the Mini so much easier to print on - at least in my experience.
The aluminium is pretty easy to drill - even with a handheld drill. Maybe you have a mate who has a drill you could use/borrow?
I'm not sure how a 3D printed version would go - it may have to much flex.
The mod is completely reversible either way, so no harm in giving it a go.
Please post back your results if you do give it a try.

remixed_from.author: cfunseth
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Zero Case (OnShape Source Included)

remixed_from.author: red9987
remixed_from.title: Pi Zero Case Remixed for Pi Zero v1.3

title: Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3 simple case

description.text:
I wanted to make some changes to the Pi Zero case and lid by red9987 and cfunseth. I re-created the design in 123D Design and made some small changes. The first is a power logo on the lid, to indicate which of the two micro-USB ports was for power, since I could never keep them straight. I also added a hole over the LED to help see the power/activity indicator. There's also a notch on the back of each cover to help open the case later. The last change was to add a block to each cover to help hold down the board inside the case when assembled. Without the block the Pi Zero kept moving around with the weight of the mini-HDMI adapter attached to it.

I added a case top with a cut-out zero logo to help with air flow for anyone that runs an overclocked board but doesn't want the gap for the IO headers.

I would suggest printing the case bottom at 100% infill, or adjust your shells to make sure the walls are solid when printed. The dividers between the USB and HDMI port are small, so without 100% fill they could be too brittle.

I printed my case with PLA+, but it should print just as well with normal PLA or PET. ABS prints might need to be scaled up to account for slight shrinking of the parts when cooled.

description.text:
with Repetier firmware and a z-probe-sensor you should use max endstop in z for homing.
Now you're able to change the height of the Z-axis, if you print a lot of small things!

(When minimizing the height, you have to change the height value in EEPROM and save it. Use a smaller value than the real one. After that you have set G29)

I developed it for my spindel prusa, but you can easilly adapt it to other systems!

title: Keychain Screwless Heart Gears
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Keychain version of Emmett's screwless heart gears!
I'm still working on getting the scale right (small enough for a keychain, but big enough to print the details)
As it is, It needs a rather large fan blowing across the print to keep the gears from getting mangled.
Current scaling = .5
All parts are the same except Gear8, which has a hole through the tip for a keyring.

Preliminary instructions:
1) Choose where you want the hole
If you want it on the top, print a regular heartgear8, and gear1forkeychain, otherwise do the opposite.
2) Print all the other gears, and the core: BEWARE, THESE ARE VERY CHALLENGING PRINTS! You may need a cooling fan blowing gently on the print, but you have to make sure it doesn't cool the platform too much and pop the print off!
3) print one of each of the pin parts, test fit them, one will fit snugly, and allow the gears to rotate, the other won't, depending on the calibration of your printer.
4) Print the rest of the pins (and probably a few extras)
5) Assemble all the parts
6) Impress your special someone on valentines day with an awesome heart keychain/pendant!

comments.text: Congrats, your model made it on my top 3D Printed Valentines Day Gifts! See here for the article: http://3dprintingninja.blogspot.com/2015/02/top-5-free-3d-printed-gifts-for.html

title: CubeX to RepRap Conversion Build - WIP

description.text:
This is my work in progress to Convert a CubeX Trio into a RepRap 3D Printer.

Features: Dual E3D V6 Hot Ends, Auto Bed Leveling and a Silicon Heated Build Plate.

This is a work and progress and I will post the progress and files of the build so others can use it if they want to do a conversion.

Left to do:
New Carraige Mount Design
Full rewire with shielded 26AWG
Rambo Connectors Digikey P/N's: WM2900-ND, WM2901-ND, WM2902-ND, WM2562CT-ND
Plexi Covers for openings with Filament Spool Holders and Hinges
Front Door
Filament Guide Mounts for the Tubes
Ambient Temp Control
Cooling Fan Mounts
Bed with Silicone Heat Pad
Camera Mount

Status Update 07/26/2016
Swapped out the Azteeg X3 for a RAMBO 1.3 and so far it's working great!
Marlin RCBUGFix Firmware added

RepRap

Prusa i3

Doesn't Matter

comments.author: Woral

comments.text: This is an old post but the info may be helpful to others. The Z sensor is a magnetic reed switch that's mounted to the X-axis carriage near the extruders. It senses a magnet that's glued to the bottom of the stock glass bed plate (one of the round metal discs). In order for the Z to be homed, the glass bed must be installed properly and the X and Y axes homed. If this is not all done, the switch won't line up with the magnet and won't sense it. I kid you not!!

author: bdillon

title: Garage door roller Solidoodle spool mount

description.text: A filament spool holder that uses garage door rollers as the ball bearings. Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97734 with the Brackets_fixed.stl, and Leftupright_fixed.stl files included here taken from that thing (but run through netfabb cloud to repair them). I cut them up and modify them in the openscad files. The spoolmount.scad file is where everything is defined. All the other scad files include it and just print one part. This also uses the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116872 tension nut to hold everything on the PVC pipe.

Get two short stem garage door rollers at your local garage door business (there is usually one nearby, which is the main reason I decided on this design). You probably want to put a little light oil on them to break up the heavy grease they are usually packed with and make them a little easier to turn. You'll need to print two of the mountingblock parts to glue to the tops of the left and right supports. I don't know how standardized garage door rollers are, but the ones I got with a nylon shell on the roller sit in these perfectly. Print four of the innerspacer parts and epoxy two to each roller stem so they'll sit in the center of a PVC pipe. (Before epoxy, it is probably a good idea to check that they fit so the rollers can slide in and out of the pipe easily since you need to slide out the roller to change the filament spool). Print two of the spoolsleeve parts. These are the "step pyramid" cones that fit in the holes in a reel of filament and center the reel on the PVC pipe. The part included here contains steps to fit in Octave and Solidoodle brand reels. You can fiddle with the openscad files to design different shapes to fit other brands of filament spools. Download and print two of these things: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116872 (Tension Nut for 3/4 inch PVC Pipe). They are used to hold the filament spool with the spoolsleeves in the center of the PVC pipe and make sure the whole thing doesn't fall apart and jam. Print one leftsupport and one rightsupport. These were tricky for me. They wanted to curl up. You might want to modify the design to add some holes or slots to the platform on the top of the support as that was where the curling always started for me. I eventually used ABS slurry on the bed to hold the part down. Glue a mountingblock to the top of each support (I used acetone with a little ABS dissolved in it as glue). Print two innerbracket parts and two outerbracket parts. These screw to either side of the support to hold the supports on the top of the printer. I found that a 6-32 tap I had would cut nice threads in the supports and with a little drilling I could fit short 6-32 bolts through the holes in the brackets for a nice solid fit. Get some 3/4 inch PVC pipe which will hold the spool of filament and rotate on the garage door rollers. Make it long enough to fit conveniently across the printer, somewhere around 9 or 10 inches. Once the supports are mounted, you can determine a good length to use. You don't want it scraping on the supports as it turns, but you want it long enough to get both garage door rollers solidly inside the pipe. Now you can put it all together. Shove a tension nut down near the far end of the pipe, follow that with a spoolsleeve, follow that with the filament spool (making sure to get the spoolsleeve inserted in the hole in the filament spool), then another spoolsleeve for the near spool hole, and another tension nut to hold everything in place. Slide the rollers into the pipe, and drop the rollers into the mountingblocks at the top of the supports, and you are done. The only thing to do is decide if you want the filament coming off the spool on the front side and directly down into the print head, or if you want to run it the other way and wrap it around through the hole in the back of the printer. The first way makes covering the printer harder, but reduces filament friction to near zero. The second way allows a fairly flat cover to go on the top of the case, but drags the filament around through holes and bends and makes the extruder motor work harder.

description.text:
I had this idea a couple days after Pokemon Go was released because I was having such a hard time throwing poke-balls straight. This card guides your finger so that you throw the pokeball straight every time. Hold the card and your phone with one hand and swipe with the other. When you have caught the pokemon slide the card off the screen and continue hunting for your next pocket monster. I am working on a curve card so stay tuned!

Video showing some tips and tricks allong with the Master Card in Action https://youtu.be/yFGxoEHE7-U

title: Soldering Station - 2 pieces, no support needed

description.text:
I remixed this because I was having a heck of a time getting the arch part to print, even with full supports. The one time it came out, it was so flimsy I couldn't use it. So, I pulled it apart, layed the arch flat, and notched the base so you can either tack it in with a couple dabs of super glue, or (preferred) a quick round of friction welding. You can print this without any supports. Enjoy!

Edit: Split the two parts in to two .STL files by request.
Edit: Added the spindle. Not sure how I missed that.
Edit: Added the correct length spindle. Not sure how I missed that :)
